description: Contributors who provide financial capital, liquidity, or risk-bearing capacity to the collective endeavor.

capital_deployed: GLITCH tokens transferred (verifiable via tx hash on chain)

contribution_capacity_justification: Capital contribution is verifiable through transaction records. However, capital alone does not create value without labor application.

freedom_from_token_theft.requirement: Staking rewards and returns as agreed in transparent on-chain terms
freedom_from_token_theft.note: Returns are contingent on system success, not guaranteed
freedom_from_token_theft.distribution_method: Staking rewards via x/distribution or governance-approved distributions

freedom_from_exploitation.requirement: No extraction of staked tokens without agreed terms
freedom_from_exploitation.constraint: Capital cannot demand disproportionate governance control
freedom_from_exploitation.limit: Returns capped per @protection_ratchet to prevent elite accumulation

freedom_to_organize.requirement: Right to investor representation in x/gov governance
freedom_to_organize.governance_weight: Proportional to staked GLITCH BUT capped to prevent capital dominance
freedom_to_organize.constraint: Capital votes cannot exceed labor votes in aggregate

freedom_from_discrimination.requirement: Equal treatment regardless of delegation size within tier
freedom_from_discrimination.access: Same on-chain information rights for all investors

protection_rationale: Capital contribution is verifiable and necessary for system growth. However, protection is constrained by @protection_ratchet to prevent capital from dominating labor.
special_constraints: Per @protection_ratchet: Capital returns cannot retroactively reduce labor compensation
Per @labor_primacy: Capital governance weight cannot exceed labor governance weight
Per @proportionality: Investor returns must be proportional to actual risk, not negotiating power

sources.citation: Piketty, T. (2014). Capital in the Twenty-First Century. Harvard University Press.
Mazzucato, M. (2018). The Value of Everything: Making and Taking in the Global Economy. PublicAffairs.
Scholz, T. (2016). Platform Cooperativism: Challenging the Corporate Sharing Economy.
